title: Seed "Find in files" from regular "find" input when focused (like VSPro)
body:
A common workflow for me when a "find" operation in the current file doesn't turn up any results is to then search for the same term across all files.
This is trivial in VSPro, where hitting [Ctrl]-[Shift]-[F] at this point brings up "Find in files" with the same search terms as the "Find" dialog.

VSCode has an unfortunate behavior here that I thought was a bug for a long time.
When pressing [Ctrl]-[Shift]-[F] after a failed local find, the "Find in files" input is seeded with a truncated version of the search terms.
What's actually happening is that "Find in files" is being seeded not with the current "find" query, but with the selected text from the current document, which, since the find failed, represents only the longest matching prefix of the actual search terms.

While seeding "find in files" from the current document selection is desirable when focus is in the document, it would be much more useful, when focus is in the "find" popup, to seed "find in files" from the full search terms there instead.

Thanks for a great tool!

title: Automate rpm signing
Search view freezes with a long single line before and after search
body:
- VSCode Version: Issue is the same in Stable, Insiders and Exploration
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open project which consists a file with a long single line
2. Type word in search view and press search
3. You will see Search View is freeze and VS Code is stuck and you can't do anything

Before rendering items in Search View it freezes and after search is done when you scroll through items it freezes. Something is really wrong if file with one single long line exist in the project.

Here is video of showing how the problem looks like:

**Search View freezes after search while scrolling through items**
https://streamable.com/uv8wl

**Search View freezes before search**
https://streamable.com/ugktu

Here is the files to reproduce it by using "Steps to Reproduce" mentioned above. Simple paste them into the new folder and try to search keyword `production`.

https://gist.github.com/svipas/227945440e2f81756eea721ddb2e65bb
https://gist.github.com/svipas/8c32e2dcc2208d78b0cf5b5390d0fc3b

_You could copy them to make at least 2 same copies to experience even worst freeze. And with real project it's 10x times worst._

I did similar test in the Atom, Sublime Text and WebStorm. All handles this problem properly and works as expected.

_For me it looks like the search itself works fine, but Search View can't handle to render items with very long lines._

/cc @roblourens

See output for more information. Source: HTML Language Features (Extension) [Go to output] ``` (even though all extensions are disabled) If I click on "Go to Output" I can see this message: ``` [Error - 17:34:36] Error while computing document symbols for file:///my/path/to/index.html: Cannot read property 'length' of undefined TypeError: Cannot read property 'length' of undefined at Object.unescapeLeadingUnderscores (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:13211:19) at tryGetName (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:105875:27) at compareChildren (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:105861:78) at Array.sort (native) at sortChildren (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:105858:22) at endNode (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:105614:17) at addNodeWithRecursiveChild (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:105621:13) at addChildrenRecursively (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:105704:21) at rootNavigationBarNode (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:105580:17) at Object.getNavigationBarItems (d:\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:105535:45) ``` The error message does not pop up, if I just open a `.js` file containing that code. title: Add a decoration render option to extend to edge of window but keep range

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
In

https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#DecorationRenderOptions

there is already a flag `isWholeLine` which extends the range across the full width of the window. It would be nice to have another similar option, which extends a multi-line range to the end of the window, but does not extend the start of the range to the beginning of the line, or the end of the range to the end of the line - just the intermediate lines.

e.g.

Current behaviour:
```
........{......................
...............................
........}......................
```
```
........{.............}........
```

Desired behaviour:
```
        {......................
...............................
........}
```
```
        {.............}
```

title: Terminal: resets history when Toggle Maximized Panel
body:
Issue Type: Bug Using Powershell as terminal: "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\WINDOWS\\System32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe", "powershell.integratedConsole.showOnStartup": false, 1. Shrink terminal down to only displaying seven lines of text. 2. Change directory to a path that has many folders 3. Type dir 4. Scroll in the terminal and verify there is a long history. 5. Click Maximize Panel Size, or use keyboard shortcut to Toggle Maximized Panel 6. Observe you are no longer able to scroll up to view the console history. Expected behavior: Console "top" is not reset and all output can be viewed Actual behavior: Console history is lost. This used to work correctly several versions ago and console history was preserved when the console was toggled. I use this by keeping my build watchers running in a small window at the bottom while I code and a hotkey to toggle the console maximize when I need to see the results of the watchers. Normally, I only need to see 3-4 lines when the watchers succeed, then when there's an error, I can toggle the maximize and scroll back to see the results. With this bug, my workflow is hindered greatly as I have to keep a separate console open and alt-tab over and over to see the results. title: Allow opening files/tabs in new windows opened through vscode.commands.executeCommand API
body:
Currently you are able to open a file path in a new VSCode window with:
```
vscode.commands.executeCommand(
  vscode.openFolder,
  vscode.Uri.file(someFilePath),
  true // true to open in new window, false to open in same window
);
```
https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/commands

However, the API does not seem to support a way to open more files in the new window in any way. It would be nice if this returned a promise (similar to other commands) so you can chain other commands to run in this new window, or provide some way to access to the new window so you can perform more operations on it.

title: Alt-Shift select does not handle arrow keys correctly
body:
Issue Type: Bug Hi, When using Alt-Shift and the mouse to select rectangles of text, it works as expected, but if the arrow keys are used instead, the results are not as expected. ## To reproduce (first case): - Put the cursor on a blank line - Hold down Alt-Shift - Press the right arrow key ## Expected result - The area to the right of the cursor should have been selected ## Result - The whole document is selected ## To reproduce (second case): - Put the cursor in the middle of a line - Hold down Alt-Shift - Press the right arrow key ## Expected result - The area to the right of the cursor should have been selected ## Result - The whole word beneath the cursor is selected VS Code version: Code 1.36.1 (2213894ea0415ee8c85c5eea0d0ff81ecc191529, 2019-07-08T22:59:35.033Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

title: Allow extensions to provide commands for their custom treeviews programatically

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
This is similar to https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/9285, but that seems to be about letting the end user configure the context menu, whereas I want to provide context menu commands from my extension, but dynamically (such that they can't be in the package manifest).

I know we've previously discussed something similar to this around making context menus *async*, but that's not required here - the context menus can be provided up-front (and periodically updated), but they are based on launch configs and therefore can't be in package.json.

Here's a screenshot fo a new feature I added to my extension:

![Screenshot 2019-08-06 at 5 23 29 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1078012/62557457-ee927600-b86e-11e9-93ac-51d90680f946.png)

The "Run" and "Debug" code lens already existed - they're hard-coded. The other two are are user-defined - the user can configure additional launch configurations for launching tests. In `provideCodeLens` I read the launch configs, see if any are marked as templates, and include them in the result.

I'd like to also add them to the context menu for the test tree here:

![Screenshot 2019-08-06 at 5 41 28 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1078012/62558721-74afbc00-b871-11e9-952f-48dd1838dc5a.png)

However AFAIC these need to be pre-declared in the package.json - and of course I don't know what custom configs the users will add. I'd like to instead supply these commands (like I do in `provideCodeLens`) for each node (either at node creation time, on-demand, or just at extension startup + whenever the user modifies the launch configs).

title: `"editor.suggestSelection": "recentlyUsed"` should be a little more sticky
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.36.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Consider the file:
```
game
gamma
```

1. Make sure `"editor.suggestSelection": "recentlyUsed"`.
1. On a new line, type `g` then select `gamma` in the autocomplete list.
1. Press space and type `g` again. `game` will be selected, despite the setting being `recentlyUsed`.

I've also encountered an issue where an option is selected with `recentlyUsed`, then I type the next character of the suggestion, and it changes to a different suggestion, despite still matching the current suggestion. As I understand it, this should not happen with `recentlyUsed`. However, I was unable to come up with a test case for this example.

title: Selectable Fast Scroll Key
body: Based on this [request](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/65072#issuecomment-515217184), it's now possible to select which key to use to activate fast scrolling. The Fast Scroll Key option allows to choose between alt (default),ctrl or shift.

title: "editor.action.blockComment" should have another shortcut
body:
It's a very very low priority thing, but maybe you can take a look.

I do not understand the idea of setting _Toggle Block Comment_ to `Shift + Alt + A`
This is very unintuitive if _Toggle Line Comment_ have a `Ctrl+ /`

It would be 100% better if you set it like this:
- Toggle Line Comment `Ctrl+ /`
- Toggle Block Comment `Ctrl + Shift + /` or `Ctrl + Alt + /`

Ok, I can edit it myself, I know it, but in my opinion it should look like this "out of the box"

title: Right click should offer remote variants of "Open with Code"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
We have fully embraced remote WSL and remote containers. We have a have a large number of projects set up for this. We would save a lot of time if we had the option to launch a folder directly into WSL or a container, especially those of us who do a lot of context switching.

Right now the flow for WSL is:
* Right-click > 'Open with Code'
* Wait for VS Code to open
* F1 > Type 'remote' 
* Choose 'Remote-WSL: Reopen folder in WSL'
* Wait for VS Code to reopen

A more efficient workflow would be:
* Right-click > 'Open with Code in WSL'
* Wait for VS Code to open

(An option for Remote-SSH should also be there, but we haven't used that yet)

title: Support NODE_OPTIONS detection for node debugger auto attach

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I'm not currently sure of the mechanism used to detect node processes but I have found auto attach does not work with `NODE_OPTIONS="--inspect-brk" ` rather than `node --inspect-brk`.

I would like to request adding this as it's helpful for when running scripts through intermediate scripts (e.g. `package.json` scripts or shell scripts).

There does seem to be a way to read the environment variables of a process for all platforms so this should be viable:
- [Windows](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.diagnostics.process.startinfo?view=netframework-4.8)
- [MacOS](https://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/140327/how-can-i-inspect-the-environment-variables-of-a-running-process)
- [Linux](https://serverfault.com/questions/66363/environment-variables-of-a-running-process-on-unix)

title: Inconsistent search results in settings editor
body:
Searching for a setting ID will sometimes produce a single result, and other times multiple results. The issue appears to be that **search results while editing the search input are different from search results that come from fresh/cleared input**.

This issue is a bit trivial, since the results still yield the target settings. It's just that they aren't consistent results. The only reason why I noticed this myself is that I'm creating a VSCode course and I wanted to mention that exact matches could be achieved by searching for a setting ID. But then I noticed that this wasn't always the case.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open the settings UI editor.
2. Search for "editor fontSize" (noting the _multiple_ results).
3. Back track with cursor (but do NOT delete).
4. Add the dot, changing input to "editor.fontSize" (noting the _multiple_ results).
5. Clear input with escape key.
6. Search for "editor.fontSize" (note the _single_ result).

**Environment:**

- VSCode Version: 1.37.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.4
- Occurs when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: vs code spawns lsof processes which gobble up CPU
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.36.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.5

MacBookPro 2018 2.7 GHz Intel Core i7 16GB 2133 MHz RAM Intel Iris Plus Graphics 655 1536 MB

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open vs code
2. Open terminal in vs code
3. Open process explorer
(3.5. use vs code or leave idle for varying periods)
4. See multiple lines of `lsof -p 27620`, each with around 64% of cpu usage (90% if extensions are enabled) while laptop fans are whirring

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
yes
